column5: Description

Collected Bong Joon-Ho movie recommendations and picks from various sources. Includes his personal opinion about the film and link to source where available. Comment on list to share new or updated sources. I will update list accordingly. BFI's Sight and Sound Poll (2012)
These films have had the biggest impact on my own personal view of cinema.
Bong Joon-ho's Top 10 via Criterion
South Korean filmmaker Bong Joon-ho is the director of The Host (2006), Mother (2009), and Snowpiercer (2013). We interviewed him for our release of the classic South Korean film The Housemaid, available in the World Cinema Project box set. After we asked him to name his favorite titles in the collection, he told us, “I actually ended up writing a wish list of Criterion Blu-rays I would like to own. For an insatiable collector like myself, limiting myself to ten films was torture.”
Bong Joon-ho's Closet Criterion Picks
The Oscar-winning director of PARASITE visited the Criterion closet back in 2014.
Film at Lincoln Center, The Bong Show - Bong Joon-Ho Selects
The Bong Show also features an eclectic carte blanche of cinematic favorites chosen by Bong Joon Ho himself, with highlights including Kim Ki-young’s folk mystery Io Island; John Frankenheimer’s sinister sci-fi drama Seconds; Henri-George Clouzot’s Palme d’Or-winning The Wages of Fear; horror classics like John Carpenter’s The Thing and John Boorman’s Deliverance; and two works from Japanese masters, Shohei Imamura‘s Intentions of Murder and Kiyoshi Kurosawa’s Cure.
[video] Birth.Death.Movies - Bong Joon-ho Discusses PARASITE, Genre Filmmaking And The Greatness Of ZODIAC
No one can dispute the greatness of Bong Joon-ho, and it’s a delight to witness the master sit down and discuss not only his new film PARASITE but his love for cinema as a whole. We were lucky to have such an opportunity and now YOU are lucky because some smart person filmed it.
[video] BETxOscars Bong Interview via Twitter
Yesterday, one of my favorite movies, "The Farewell", won the Independent Spirit award for Best Picture.

From Bong's Criterion Top 10
The most beautiful feature film debut in the history of cinema. I’m extremely curious about the abundant special features on the Blu-ray. I wish to explore every single one.

From Bong's Criterion Top 10
The most beautiful ending to a feature film career in the history of cinema. And the most beautiful DVD box set in the history of mankind. I’m keen to find out who the designer of the box set was.

From Bong's Criterion Top 10
I would like to compare the film to The Ballad of Narayama by Shohei Imamura and Goryeojang by Kim Ki-young. I wish to fully experience and appreciate Keisuke Kinoshita’s bold colors through Blu-ray.

From Bong's Criterion Top 10
I’m anxious to find out if I will be as thoroughly excited by the film as I was by H. G. Wells’s science fiction novels when I read them as a youth.

From Bong's Criterion Top 10
It’s Max Ophüls!

From Bong's Criterion Top 10
There have been many “tapestry films,” including Altman’s own Short Cuts and Paul Thomas Anderson’s Magnolia. But I believe Nashville will always be the best in the class.

From Bong's Criterion Top 10
The actors/characters in Mike Leigh’s films are always shockingly vivid and alive.

column2: The Man Who Fell to Earth
column5:
From Bong's Criterion Top 10
Nicolas Roeg’s films never cease to be fresh and youthful.

From Bong's Criterion Top 10
Wes Anderson’s films are delightfully strange and endearing.

From Bong's Criterion Top 10
A few days ago, I had a chance to meet Spike Jonze, and we talked briefly. The meeting left me with a strong impulse to go inside his head and explore the corners of his mind.

Film at Lincoln Center, The Bong Show - Bong Joon-Ho Selects
In John Boorman’s infamous back-country thriller, starring Jon Voight and a breakout Burt Reynolds, four city boys make the foolhardy decision to canoe down a treacherous Georgia river before it’s dammed and turned into a lake.

Film at Lincoln Center, The Bong Show - Bong Joon-Ho Selects
After being assaulted by a burglar, housewife Sadako finds herself deeply conflicted in Shohei Imamura’s psychologically arresting and sensuously shot portrait of fear and desire.

Film at Lincoln Center, The Bong Show - Bong Joon-Ho Selects
This bizzare murder mystery from one of Korean cinema’s unquestionable masters, Kim Ki-young (The Housemaid), is a fascinating interrogation of Korean identity in the 1970s and a hypnotic take on the missing-person story.

Film at Lincoln Center, The Bong Show - Bong Joon-Ho Selects
A depressed middle-aged banker agrees to a procedure that will fake his death and give him a completely new look and identity—at a dangerous price. Starring Rock Hudson, Seconds is a sci-fi nightmare about the primordial concerns of eternal youth and a bleak reappraisal of the American Dream.

Film at Lincoln Center, The Bong Show - Bong Joon-Ho Selects
In John Carpenter’s chilling (and sometimes hilarious) remake of the 1951 classic, the staff of an Antarctic research outpost battles a shape-shifting alien lifeform in an atmosphere of escalating paranoia.

Bong Joon Ho & Tom Quinn Talk 'Parasite,' 'Mad Max' & Marvel
I am a huge fan, crazy fan, of the second one: The Road Warrior. I watched it more than 20-30 times.

BETxOscars Bong Interview
Yesterday, one of my favorite movies, "The Farewell", won the Independent Spirit award for Best Picture. I was so happy, we all screamed and shouted. We really love Lulu Wang, such a great female Asian-American female director. We were so happy with her.

Bong Joon-ho's Closet Criterion Picks
In Korea, when I was in junior high, there were so many Nastassja Kinski fans. Based on Thomas Hardy's Tess. It was a big hit in Korea.

Bong Joon-ho's Closet Criterion Picks
I already have this movie on DVD but, first time with Blu-Ray. And also, amazing special features, and documentaries. Many "making of".

Bong Joon-ho's Closet Criterion Picks
Of all of Kurosawa's Shakespeare adaptations, this one is my favorite.

Bong Joon-ho's Closet Criterion Picks
When I was young, I saw this on TV in Korea, and it made a big impression on me. I can see it again on Blu-ray now.

Bong Joon-ho's Closet Criterion Picks
This is one of the greatest movies by Peter Weir. Oh, it comes with the novel.

Bong Joon-ho's Closet Criterion Picks
This is my favorite of Guillermo's Spanish language films, though Pan's Labyrinth is also beautiful.

I used to have the DVD a long time ago but Park Chan-wook borrowed it. He swiped it, and never gave it back.

Bong Joon-ho's Closet Criterion Picks
Repo Man is one of Alex Cox's best films, and I'm happy to see it on Blu-ray.
